Blog.post: Last night I watched the news (which is not something I do often) and I have to say I was appalled. Appalled at the way teenagers in this country are portrayed. Firstly, there was the naming of the schoolboy killer – Alan Pennell, a 16-year-old who killed Luke Walmsley. Now, while this is a horrific tragedy, the branding of a 16-year-old as evil shocks me to the core. We are so quick to blame; surely the questions we should ask are, What made a 16-year-old go to these lengths to be heard? Were the adults around Alan aware of the conflict emerging between him and Luke? Why was there no adequate intervention? What are we doing as a society? But no, we go into a moral panic and the media brands a child as evil. Then to top it all, eleven teenagers were given an anti-social behaviour order – eleven teenagers branded as criminals because they had nothing better to do. Now believe me, I have dealt with teenagers like this for over 10 years, so I am not looking at this with rose-tinted glasses and I do not in any way condone the behaviour, but is this the answer? What are we doing to our youths today? And then, if you just were not convinced that the word teenager meant the Anti-Christ, a whole report dealing with how our teenagers are sexually promiscuous and spreading diseases. In thirty minutes, we as a country had firmly told the world that the word teenager = bad. Is it any wonder that they behave that way?

As I sit here feeling very sorry for myself, (I’ve got a cold) I am reflecting on the week gone by. I spent three hours with a leading TV media company the other day, speaking about two forthcoming projects – this was very exciting, something I have dreamed of for a long time. I went there all prepared, thinking that I was looking my best, only to come out after the meeting, look in the mirror to see that not only was I having a very bad hair day, I also had a piece of bread between my teeth. Will I ever learn? Look in the mirror first! I got to hand a media opportunity over to Dan, one of my team, this week. That felt so good, finally not having to bear all the burdens, and now someone else knows how I feel. He called me after and said that it was so scary. All I could say in reply was, “Welcome to my world!” Tee-hee!

Sarah

Well another great week, made all the better by spending a few days on my Dad’s canal boat. Two things make this special. Firstly, the fact that I get to spend time with my Dad after his life-threatening brain haemorrhage and secondly, I get to slow down and see what is important about life; being present with the people that matter. So who do you need to slow down and be present with this week?
